ARABIC: لَوْ نَشَآءُ لَجَعَلْنَٰهُ حُطَٰمًا فَظَلْتُمْ تَفَكَّهُونَ

ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_0: If We wished We could have made it broken stubble. You would then be left devoid of crops, distraught:
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_1: We could turn it, if We pleased, into straw; then you would rue the day,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_2: If We so wished, We could have reduced your harvest to rubble, and you would have been left wonder-struck to exclaim:
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_3: Had We wanted, We could have crushed it to bits and you would have been left to lament,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_4: If We will We can make it like dry trampled hay, so you would keep crying out.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_5: Were it Our will, We could crumble it to dry pieces, and you would be Tafakkahun.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_6: If We pleased, We should have certainly made it broken down into pieces, then would you begin to lament:
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_7: Did We will, We would make it broken orts, and you would remain bitterly jesting --
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_8: If We willed, We verily could make it chaff, then would ye cease not to exclaim:
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_9: If We so pleased, We could turn your harvest into chaff. Then you would start lamenting,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_10: If We willed, surely We would make it chaff, so that ye would be left wondering.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_11: If We wish, We turn it into chaff, whereat you are left stunned [saying to yourselves,]
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_12: Were it Our Will, We could crumble it to dry powder, and ye would be left in wonderment,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_13: Were it Our Will, We could crumble it to dry pieces, and you would be regretful (or left in wonderment).
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_14: If We will, We would make it broken stubble and you would remain wondering,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_15: If We will, We can turn it into rubble; then you will lament.
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_16: If We willed, We could make it [dry] debris, and you would remain in wonder,
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_17: [56:65] If We will, We could surely turn it into chaff, dried vegetation producing no seed, and you would remain (zaltum is actually zaliltum, the lām having a kasra inflection; but it has been omitted to soften it), that is to say, you spend all day, bemused (tafakkahūna: one of the original tā’ [tatafakkahūna] letters has been omitted), surprised by this, and you would say:
ENGLISH.TRANSLATION_18: (If We willed, We verily could make it) the cultivation (chaff) and dry after being green, (then would ye cease not to exclaim) then you would wonder at its dryness and destruction, and exclaim:
